results.headline: Review: ‘Class Divide’ Shows the Extremes Hypergentrification Creates in a Neighborhood
results.summary_short: This Marc Levin documentary centers on a single intersection in Manhattan: on one side, public housing; on the other side, an elite private school.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Class Divide

results.headline: Review: ‘Neon Bull,’ With Creatures Great and Small
results.summary_short: Gabriel Mascaro’s film explores the connections between humans and animals played out against the setting of the Brazilian rodeo event known as vaquejada.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Neon Bull

results.headline: Review: ‘Mr. Right,’ With Anna Kendrick, Dips Into a Tricky Genre
results.summary_short: This hybrid action thriller and romantic comedy follows Martha, who meets a blithe charmer and discovers that he’s a hit man.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Right

results.headline: Review: ‘11 Minutes,’ a Whirl of Intersecting Tales Heading Toward Combustion
results.summary_short: Jerzy Skolimowski’s film yields an illusion of simultaneous forward motion for events that are both extremely lucid and inscrutable.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 11 Minutes

results.headline: Review: In ‘Louder Than Bombs,’ a Father and Sons Grieving
results.summary_short: Gabriel Byrne, Jesse Eisenberg, Isabelle Huppert and Amy Ryan head the cast of Joachim Trier’s first English-language film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Louder Than Bombs

results.headline: Review: In ‘The Invitation,’ Welcome to a Chiller Dinner
results.summary_short: In this film directed by Karyn Kusama, there’s something off about the hostess, her lair of a house and some of the guests.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Invitation

results.headline: Review: In ‘Demolition,’ It’s Hammer Time for Jake Gyllenhaal
results.summary_short: Mr. Gyllenhaal portrays a banker recovering from the loss of his wife, with Naomi Watts playing a customer service representative who draws his attention.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Demolition

results.headline: Review: Melissa McCarthy Takes Charge in ‘The Boss’
results.summary_short: Playing a fallen investment guru, Ms. McCarthy employs her precision comedic timing in a film that’s mostly another rung on her big ladder up.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boss

results.headline: Review: ‘Look at Us Now, Mother!,’ a Documentary of a Family and Its Discontents
results.summary_short: In a film that promises an “epic journey” to explore her family’s “long-buried suffering,” the director, Gayle Kirschenbaum, interviews her mother, now in her 90s.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Look at Us Now, Mother!

results.headline: Review: ‘High Strung’ Finds a Dancer and Musician Colliding
results.summary_short: The movie, in which two young artists fall for each other, is energized by Dave Scott’s choreography.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of High Strung

results.headline: Review: In ‘Hardcore Henry,’ a Semi-Robotic Soldier Has a Personal Mission
results.summary_short: This Ilya Naishuller film has the look of a first-person-shooter video game.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hardcore Henry

results.headline: Review: In ‘One More Time,’ a Dysfunctional Family Sings
results.summary_short: In this Robert Edwards film, Christopher Walken plays a crooner seeking a comeback, and Amber Heard is his daughter, who has a voice but little drive.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One More Time

results.headline: Review: ‘Havana Motor Club’ Explores Car Racing in Cuba
results.summary_short: Bent-Jorgen Perlmutt’s documentary shows that Cuba’s automotive heritage feeds a racing culture, despite years of government limitations on competitions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Havana Motor Club

results.display_title: Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt
results.headline: Review: In ‘Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt,’ a Thinker More Relevant Than Ever
results.summary_short: This documentary examines the controversies over Arendt’s coverage of the Eichmann war crimes trial and her writings on totalitarianism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt

results.headline: Review: ‘Standing Tall,’ a Boy’s Encounter With the Law
results.summary_short: Emmanuelle Bercot’s film, with Rod Paradot as a violent boy, and Catherine Deneuve as a magistrate, examines France’s approach to juvenile justice.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Standing Tall

results.headline: Review: In ‘Too Late,’ Imitation Is Sincere Flattery
results.summary_short: Noir pays tribute to noir, with respect, in this film by Dennis Hauck, starring John Hawkes as a private investigator determined to avenge a murder.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Too Late

results.headline: Review: ‘The Dark Horse’ Dramatizes the Tale of a Chess Coach
results.summary_short: “The Dark Horse,” a film inspired by a documentary, is about Gen Potini, a Maori speed-chess player who used his skill to help young players.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dark Horse

results.headline: Review: ‘Miles Ahead,’ an Impressionistic Take on Miles Davis
results.summary_short: Don Cheadle stars in — and directed — this biopic about the jazz trumpeter, who was a sly chameleon, both in his life and in his music.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miles Ahead

results.headline: Review: In ‘Afternoon,’ Two Men Open Up
results.summary_short: This Tsai Ming-liang film features him and the actor Lee Kang-sheng discussing personal issues in a minimalist setting.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Afternoon

results.headline: Review: In ‘Kill Your Friends,’ Corporate Climbing Can Prove Deadly
results.summary_short: The Britpop scene of the ‘90s takes it squarely on the chin in this blisteringly bleak yet richly satisfying poison-pen letter to the music industry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kill Your Friends
